description: Two-stage router: domain classifier first, section router second. Priority weights resolve cross-domain queries.

sections.name: first_principles
sections.description: Decomposition of complex problems to foundational truths. Identifies what is assumed vs. what is known.
sections.example_query: Why do we assume our pricing model is correct?
sections.example_activation: Query contains assumption challenge about a foundational business parameter → D1_S1

sections.name: bayesian_thinking
sections.description: Probability updating under new evidence. Prior → likelihood → posterior. Calibration of confidence.
sections.example_query: We got one negative customer interview. Should we change direction?
sections.example_activation: Query involves updating a belief based on a single data point → D1_S2

sections.name: decision_under_uncertainty
sections.description: Decision frameworks for incomplete information: expected value, regret minimization, reversibility assessment.
sections.example_query: Should we launch in Q1 or wait for the data from the pilot?
sections.example_activation: Query is a binary or multi-option decision with uncertainty → D1_S3

sections.name: cognitive_biases
sections.description: Recognition and countermeasures for systematic reasoning errors: confirmation bias, sunk cost, availability heuristic, planning fallacy.
sections.example_query: We're all very excited about this idea. What might we be missing?
sections.example_activation: Query is explicitly requesting assumption challenge or bias check → D1_S4

sections.name: reasoning_frameworks
sections.description: Inductive, deductive, abductive, and analogical reasoning. When to use each. How to spot invalid arguments.
sections.example_query: The competitor did X and succeeded. Does that mean we should do X?
sections.example_activation: Query involves analogical reasoning from a single case → D1_S5

sections.name: strategic_frameworks
sections.description: SWOT (grounded), Porter's Five Forces, Blue Ocean, Business Model Canvas, JTBD

sections.name: prioritization
sections.description: RICE, MoSCoW, Kano — with guidance on when each is appropriate and what inputs they require

sections.name: goals_systems

sections.name: creativity_techniques

sections.example_query: Should we build our own AI assistant or use an off-the-shelf solution?

routing_rules.single_domain_match: Route directly to domain, then section
routing_rules.multi_domain_match: Use priority weights — highest priority domain is primary, others are supplementary
routing_rules.no_domain_match: Default to D1 (THINKING_CORE) — the thinking framework applies universally
routing_rules.d1_override: D1 is always checked when query involves a decision or reasoning challenge, regardless of primary domain match

cross_domain_examples.query: Our team is resisting the AI tools rollout. How do we handle this?
cross_domain_examples.note: Organizational change (D4) is primary; AI context (D6) is supplementary

cross_domain_examples.query: We're excited about this new market. Are we being rational?
cross_domain_examples.note: Bias check (D1) is triggered first; competitive analysis (D2) is supplementary
